title: Another great Italian job by flying Hanna
story: NEWCASTLE ACrsquos Zak Hanna was back in action again last weekend in the Italian Mountain Racing Championships as he continued his recent fine form with another impressive show.Three weeks after his brilliant racing weekend in Lombardy, where he took third and fth place finishes, the Dromore flyer was back in northern Italy for the nd version of the Challenge Stellina in Susa, north-west of Turin.Zak, along with Sylvain Cachard of France and Sloveniarsquos Miran Cvet, were the only non-Italians in the race.A two-hour flight on Friday morning, having battled from am in the autumnal storm to Dublin, saw Hanna land in a hot and sunny Milano Bergamo.. He took trains from Milan to Torino, and then up the Susa Valley and around six hours later he was installed in Susa where it was  degrees.Race day dawned without a cloud in the sky and with the temperature already soaring, Hanna joined the front row of the grid designed for social distancing wearing his mask. The mask was obligatory for the first m. Hanna tucked into a front bunch that was a whorsquos who of Italian mountain racing. Hanna covered the first mile in :, and then at km the race became steep. He climbed well, as ever, encountering a dficult patch around the middle and then at about .km he spotted Baldaccini ahead of him, a past winner in  and .By now Hanna was in tenth place and with his climbing legs feeling good again set about moving up the field. He caught Baldaccini and kept pushing and on to the final k, with  flats and true flats at over , feet altitude, Hanna surged to cross the line in a brilliant eighth place.In the process he had taken the scalps of, not just the former winner of the race Baldaccini, but also Puppi, who had taken second place in last yearrsquos World Long-Distance Mountain Racing Championships, and Bernard Dematteis, the former European mountain racing champion.At Down Royal on Saturday, the sound of hi-tec racing flats reverberated around the horse racing turf as the ChampionChip Ireland Road Race Series continued following its event at Eikon, Balmoral, three weeks ago.It was only August , but could easily have been mistaken for late autumn as the blustery conditions from the remnants of tropical Storm Ellen continued to cause havoc in the quest for personal bests.It was a testament to the consistent running many had done during lockdown and throughout the winter before that there were many personal bests achieved.First up was the km, won by Mourne man Andrew Annett in : in a sprint finish with Annadalersquos Eskander Turki . Three weeks ago, David McNeilly, who now graces the ranks of the M category, ran a k PB of :and came home in : for a PB of  seconds dating back over seven years.Next clubman home was Niall Goodman in :, just three seconds outside the time he set at Eikon, he was slightly disappointed but the run consolidates the improvement he has made this year. The ever-improving Francis Tumelty is now in the M category and after just missing out on his K PB three weeks ago with a : clocking in Eikon, he smashed his : from the Bay Road k in  with a : PB here at Down Royal.Fteen year old Tom Crudgington doesnrsquot much like running on the flat mdash instead he loves the hills and mountains. However, hersquos learning that he needs to improve his running on the flat to take it into the mountains and here he set a PB by around a minute with his : time. Phil Murdock broke the -minute barrier for the first time clocking :.Mark Holland has shown steady improvement in training and is another who is getting faster as he gets older, now in the M category. With a previous best of around  and a half minutes, he smashed that with a brilliant : clocking, a fine product for all the work he has done.Nichola Watson has had injury troubles, but over the past couple of months has been training consistently again. Wondering beforehandshe would be strong enough to dip under  minutes, she put any doubt to rest with a brilliantly paced race to record a letime best of :.Also ing to racing, this time less than six months after giving birth to baby Roacutenaacuten, Ashlene Mussen surprised herself in recording a very strong :.Next up was the half-marathon and as ever a glutton for real punishment, Thomas OrsquoGorman toed the line on the back of his :: PB at Eikon three weeks ago. With conditions a bit harder here, he had to settle for :: and a th place.The final race of the day was the k where Lisburn ACrsquos Chris Madden won in an excellent :.Three weeks ago, Aidy Brown was gutted to run  seconds outside  minutes and  seconds outside his best and he vowed totoday and put the record straight. He ran brilliantly to record a big PB of . and dip under the -minute barrier for the first time.James King has been a revelation over the past year and after a wee hiatus during the first half of lockdown has put in a very consistent block of training. He was rewarded with a big PB on Saturday of . and also demonstrated he has learned the art of how to run a quick time ndash . for the first k and a swter . for the second half.At Eikon three weeks earlier, Frank Cunningham had run a PB of . and today came back and blew that out of the water to record . and a PB by  seconds. Also competing, were Paul and Aacuteine Gosling with Paul aiming to help Aacuteine break  minutes.t turned out to be a very tough day at the office with the pair coming home in .  . respectively ndash really disappointing for Aacuteine after all the excellent training, but tomorrowrsquos another day.After a lean spell of racing that even led him to vow maybe to never run another k, Gerard McAuley or GMAC to his acquaintances demonstrated that he was getting back to good fitness with a well-judged ., a . first half and a . second half..prettyPhoto

title: Bryansford stun Clonduff in second half comeback
story: BRYANSFORD pulled off a sensational win over Clonduff with two goals at critical times proving the dference after extra-time in this pulsating Morgan Fuels Down Senior Football Championship second round clash.Clonduff made the brighter start and picked off the first three minor scores by the first water break of the game on what was a warm afternoon. At that stage, Bryansford had work to do with Clonduff leading - to -.Charlie Carr split the posts for Clonduff with a superbly taken score. Aidan Carr also got in on the act scoring a minor from play and Stephen McConville got his name on the scoresheet.Aidan Carr added another point and on  minutes the lead was extended further when Arthur McConville landed a big free to make it - to -.Bryansford needed something to steady the ship and they managed it on  minutes, getting their first score on the board when a free from Cathal Burns cut the gap to four points.Clonduff, however, were in no mood to get a case of the jitters and indeed stretched their lead to - to - when, in the th minute, firstly Tom Close got the better of his marker to break free to land another score, and then moments later, Barry OrsquoHagan did likewise.Bryansford were in need of some kind of encouragement and Danny Savage provided it on  minutes when he landed a free.Darren OrsquoHagan however went up the field and confidently steered between the posts to put Clonduff - to - ahead at the half-time interval.Early in the second period, Clonduff kept the foot on the gas to flatten the Bryansford spirit even more.Paddy Brannigan engineered just enough space for himself to punt the ball over Mark Reidrsquos crossbar.And then on  minutes it was - to - when Aidan Carr capitalised on space in the lsquoFord defence to leave Clonduff in the box seat.Clonduff were finding space more and more easy to come by and from a free after five minutes Stephen McConville made it - to -.Bryansford remained honest in the battle and made their third impression on the scoreboard when David McKenna pointed on  minutes.Clonduffrsquos machine was starting to purr productively and they rolled the scoreboard over once more ten minutes after the resumption when Stephen McConville knocked the ball over from play.The sides swapped scores on the -minute mark of the contest when David McKibbin made another minor from a free for lsquoFord, but Stephen McConville pointed for Clonduff to make it - to -.Fintan Canavan scored Bryansfordrsquos fth point before Stephen McConville responded in kind to again leave a nine-point cushion between them.The final minor before the next water break though went the way of Bryansford, Timmy Hanna notching it to make it - to -.In the th minute of the contest, Cathal Burns pointed Bryansfordrsquos seventh point. Savage kept pushing lsquoFord forward, using his experience to encourage those around him, and he knocked over their eighth score of the contest.Barely  seconds later it was Savage again scoring to give lsquoFord some real hope. That set up something of a tense finish to the contest when it had looked like it would be anything but.Twenty four minutes into the second half, Savage again was the commander-in-chief of the counter-offensive, making it three points in a row for Bryansford to cut the scoreline to - to -.A free gave Bryansford and Savage the chance to leave just a goal between the sides, and he made no mistakes, confidently floating his effort between the sticks, continuing his spell as a one-man danger to Clonduffrsquos superiority.However, as the clock began to become the enemy of lsquoFord, Clonduffrsquos Tom Close pointed from play to give Clonduff that crucial lead of four ahead again.Cathal Burns curled a neat point over the bar for Bryansford going into injury time to make it - to -.Then came a moment to stun Clonduff when Bryansford found a goal. Conor Maginn pumped the ball into the area and there was Timmy Hanna to palm it into the back of the net and force the game into extra time.The first ten-minute period of was a cagey affair, with both sides understandably more keen to avoid mistakes than push forward too much.Seven minutes into the first period, the first score was registered by Savage for Bryansford mdash it was the only score of that first spell.In the first minute of the second period Stephen McConville sent over a free, his seventh point of the afternoon. And when Barry OrsquoHagan pointed a moment later, Clonduff edged ahead by a point.That was clawed back again though when, eight minutes into the second period, Peter Brannigan equalised to leave the score - to -.Brannigan, however, was to make an even bigger splash just when this game seemed to have given you everything in twists and turns.He cashed in on a tiring Clonduff defence and fired beyond beyond the flailing efforts of goalkeeper Neil Trainor for a goal, to the delight of the lsquoFord contingent. Clonduff were floored and Paddy Sheridan put the seal on the victory with a final point for Bryansford.Clonduff: Neil Trainor, Lorcan Brannigan, Mark McPolin, Ruairi Lively, Darren OrsquoHagan, Shane McGreevy, Paddy Brannigan , Tom Close , Ross Carr, Charlie Carr , Aidan Carr , Paul Lively, Stephen McConville , Arthur McConville , Barry OrsquoHagan . title: Co Down inventor celebrated in new book
story: A FORMER Downpatrick man has written a book about a pioneering Co Down cardiologist who revolutionised emergency heart treatment.Professor Frank Pantridge, who was from Hillsborough, achieved global recognition as the inventor of the worldrsquos first portable heart defibrillator  years ago.Since then his invention has gone on to save the lives of countless thousands of people around the world, including a former US President.However, as a young doctor serving in the British Army in the Far East during the Second World War it seemed unlikely that he would live long enough to become a respected and admired figure in the medical world.Taken prisoner at the fall of Singapore in , Frank Pantridge survived three-and-a-half years of brutal Japanese captivity on the notorious Burma Railway where the death rate among Allied prisoners was appalling.His remarkable story is the subject of a new book by Cecil Lowry, who was born and reared in Downpatrick, but now lives in Stockport in England.Cecil had a career in sports management, but retired in  to concentrate on writing. lsquoFrank Pantridge MC, Japanese Prisoner of War and Inventor of the Portable Defibrillatorrsquo is his fourth book and follows three others which examine the brutality of the Japanese during WW.The shocking extent of that brutality is all too familiar to Cecil, whose father, Hugh, was also taken prisoner by the Japanese following the fall of Singapore and educed the horrors of working on what became known as the lsquoDeath Railwayrsquo. Like Pantridge, after the war he could neither forgive nor forget and had a burning hatred of the Japanese.During his time in captivity, Pantridge suffered badly from malnutrition, beri beri and other illnesses. Following the Japanese surrender he weighed less than five stone and was a physical wreck.On ing home to Northern Ireland in October  he was still very weak, but was determined to resume his medical career, getting a housemanrsquos position at the Royal Victoria Hospital.Because of his experiences in the POW camps, he decided to specialise in heart medicine. He became a consultant physician and cardiologist at the RVH before inventing the portable defibrillator in the s.Pantridge had become convinced that a patient might be savedan electric shock was applied to the chest as soon as possible after a cardiac arrest. There were defibrillators in hospitals, but they were too big and bulky to be taken outside.Along with others he set out to make a defibrillator small enough to fit inside an ambulance. In  the first ambulance with a defibrillator was operating in Northern Ireland, making the province one of the safest places in the world to have a heart attack.The mobile defibrillator was used to treat US President Lyndon Johnson when he suffered a heart attack in .Although he was known worldwide as the lsquoFather of Emergency Medicinersquo Pantridge was less acclaimed in his own country, and was saddened that it took until  for all front-line ambulances in the UK to be fitted with defibrillators.He had retired in  and died on December , , aged . A bronze statue of him stands outside Lisburnrsquos civic centre as a timeless tribute to his achievements.Cecil Lowry says of Professor Pantridge: ldquoFrank was a man, whose talents and achievements were so extraordinary, that the further we consider his character, the more he will be remembered by the present generation with admiration and reverence.ldquoThis book has told the manrsquos story of incredible bravery in the face of overwhelming odds during the Second World War and his dedication to the concept of the portable defibrillator on his . He was part of the lsquoforgotten armyrsquo and more than  years on, with very few still alive, it is a privilege to set the record straight and to honour him.lsquoFrank Pantridge MC, Japanese Prisoner of War and Inventor of the Portable Defibrillatorrsquo is published by Pen  Sword Books Ltd and is priced pound...prettyPhoto

title: Dedicated crossings for school children on Strangford ferry
story: DEDICATED sailings for school children are to be introduced on the Strangford ferry service from next week.The Department for Infrastructure will provide a foot passenger only service from either side of the waterway from next Tuesday.Students will cross from Portaferry at .am and from Strangford at pm, with the sailings co-ordinated with Translink to ensure that there are buses to ferry children to and from school.Confirmation of the new service mdash which requires all passengers to wear face masks mdash comes after a number of children were refused permission to board the ferry on Monday morning from the Portaferry side.Only  foot passengers were permitted on the sailing due to coronavirus restrictions which forced children to wait for the vessel to , sparking criticism from Strangford MLA Kellie Armstrong and local councillor Joe Boyle.Mrs Armstrong, who for a number of weeks has highlighted the issue of limited passenger numbers and how students travelling on the ferry would be accommodated, has raised her concerns with Stormont education minister Peter Weir.She said that her fears were confirmed on Monday when only  foot passengers were permitted per sailing which resulted in some students having to miss two subsequent sailings before they could cross the lough, missing buses to Downpatrick.Mrs Armstrong said she was also concerned that children had to wait for up to one hour with little access to shelter, before yesterdayrsquos storm force conditions.ldquoSchoolsat the end of August every year and social distancing has been in place for months.ldquoAnyone with any transport planning ability would have ensured there was a solution, recognising the number needing to cross on the ferry as foot passengers and enabling students to travel safely, she said ahead of yesterdayrsquos confirmation about the new passenger service.ldquoI contacted the Minister for Infrastructure who confirmed weeks ago that her department was waiting on education officials to clary how many students needed to cross and sailing times.In a letter to Mr Weir, the Strangford MLA suggested that officials ldquofailed to meet the start of school deadline and as a result students were not being provided with appropriate home to school transport.Mrs Armstrong said that in the pastthe ferry could not be used, students were bused around the peninsula and asked why this option was not considered.Cllr Boyle said that what happened on Monday morning impacted on students who attend schools in Downpatrick and Ballynahinch.ldquoI simply cannot believe that as we entered the last week in August with Minister Weir trumpeting the importance of ato school that there was little or no advanced preparation or thought for children and parents within the Ards peninsula. The way they have been treated is diabolical, he declared.Cllr Boyle said parents have raised their concerns with him, highlighting what their children experienced at the start of the new school term by having to wait to use the ferry.He also revealed that he became increasingly concerned when he highlighted the issue on social media and was told how children were being treated.Cllr Boyle said problems were compounded with the closure of the main Strangford to Downpatrick road to allow a number of trees to be pruned to allow double decker buses to use the route in future.ldquoMy main concern is that there was no prior notice in relation to the number of children who could board the ferry. Parents also were not told, he continued.Cllr Boyle also commended two St Patrickrsquos Grammar School students who were waiting for the ferry on Monday but stood back to allow two elderly people to board the vessel.ldquoOnce they had boarded, the students were not allowed on as there were  foot passengers. They were the only two left at the quayside before being joined by other passengers waiting to cross on the next sailing. Those in authority need to address this issue immediately, he added.Announcing that the new dedicated service for foot passengers starts from next week, the Department for Infrastructure has confirmed that an off-schedule service will operate on weekdays at .am, am, pm and pm..prettyPhoto

title: Delay to Belfast aquarium proposal
story: BELFAST City Council has deferred a decision on plans for a proposed poundm aquarium at the Titanic Quarter which, it is claimed, feared will impact on an existing facility in Portaferry and devastate the local tourism sector.The decision not to press ahead with a plannersrsquo recommendation to approve the multi-million pound scheme was taken last week.It came after Strangford MLA Kellie Armstrong appealed to Stormont infrastructure minister Nichola Mallon to take the decision out of the hands of city councillors.Mrs Armstrong made the appeal amid increasing concern about the ldquodevastating impact the multi-million pound proposal for Belfastrsquos Titanic Quarter will have on the Exploris aquarium in Portaferry.Six years ago, the future of the local aquarium and visitor facility was under threat, but a major campaign supported by the community and politicians secured financial backing for a much-needed makeover at the tourist attraction which is crucial to the economy on both sides of the internationally acclaimed waterway.A final decision on the Belfast aquarium was deferred by city councillors last week to allow the Department for Infrastructure to carry out a traffic review.The Strangford MLA said it is her understanding that the impact the Belfast proposal would have on tourism along the Ards peninsula was not discussed last week.However, she confirmed that she has raised her concerns with Mrs Mallon and the government departmentrsquos chief planner, Angus Kerr, asking for the application to be lsquocalled inrsquo which would take the final decision away from the council.Mrs Armstrong also confirmed that Ards and North Down Council has submitted an objection to the Belfast aquarium proposal, with the number of other objections also increasing.She said Cllr Lorna McAlpine has been working with the local authority to raise concern and encourage the organisation to make formal objection.Those behind the Belfast project estimate that the proposed aquarium could attract as many as , visitorseach year,planning approval is secured.Ms Armstrong ndash who was heavily involved in the Save Exploris campaign a few years ago ndash saidthe Titanic Quarter aquarium is allowed to proceed, it would ldquodevastate the local tourism sector in the Ards peninsula.She declared: ldquoThere is absolutely no necessity for another aquarium in Northern Ireland, especially when we already have an excellent facility on the Ards peninsula.ldquoIf this planning application is allowed to progress it will have a signicant detrimental economic impact on the existing Exploris aquarium, on the rural village of Portaferry and tourism in general on the rural Ards peninsula.Ahead of last weekrsquos planning meeting in Belfast when the approval recommendation was deferred, Ms Armstrong said the city council was expected to pass the application ldquowithout appreciating the signicant impact the development will have in another council area.She said this is why the infrastructure minister must call in the application before it proceeds any further.Mrs Armstrong continued: ldquoThis particular planning application has regional signicance and a detrimental impact on a rural area.ldquoThatrsquos why I have written to Minister Mallon to press the case of all those whose livelihoods depend on the tourism impact of the Exploris. The Minister cannot allow all this to simply be thrown away.The Strangford MLA added: ldquoThe local community previously stood together to save Exploris and will do so again. I would urge anyone with concerns to make their voice heard and lodge their concerns and together we can save our local economy.It is believed that the poundm aquarium proposal could create more than  full-time jobs and would be the biggest attraction of its kind on the island of Ireland.The firm behind it, reefLIVE, says around  to  jobs could be created during its construction, with  full-time posts created when it opens its doors, subject to securing planning approval..prettyPhoto

title: Down Leisure Centre lights up blue in memory of Noah
story: DOWN Leisure Centre in Downpatrick was illuminated blue last Saturday evening in remembrance of Belfast schoolboy Noah Donohoe who tragically died in June.The Market Street facility was lit up by Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairwoman Laura Devlin.She said Noahrsquos disappearance sparked a huge community response across Northern Ireland with a lsquoRemembering Noahrsquo campaign started by the -year-oldrsquos mother Fiona.ldquoThis illumination marked nine weeks since young Noah went missing and it is hoped it will help create awareness for the ongoing appeal for information surrounding his death, said Cllr Devlin.ldquoAs a mother, I am devastated at the loss that Fiona Donohoe is going through and would like to extend my support to her and her family.The council chairwoman said that illuminating local authority buildings, including Newry Town Hall, was both to honour Noahrsquos memory and to raise awareness of the continuing appeal for information.She also issued a reminder that people across the district can continue to raise awareness about Noah by using #remembermynoah.Cllr Devlin added: ldquoI would appeal to anyone with any evidence or information in respect of Noahrsquos disappearance to bring this immediately to the authorities..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C August 26%2C 2000
story: NEWCASTLE ndash Down councillors have this week heard an impassioned plea for the character of one of Newcastlersquos oldest areas to be retained.Residents in King Street and the nearby harbour fear the area is ripe to be picked off at will by developers and have appealed for help so the area can be preserved.Members of the recently formed Newcastle Harbour Area Community Association briefed councillors on the impact new developments are having in the resort on Monday night and hope their concerns will be taken on board.In a bid to protect the heritage of the area for future generations, residents have suggested King Street and the harbour could be designated as a conservation area in a bide to restrict the number of new townhouses and apartments.Mr. Bernard Davey, who was joined by Mr. Des Farley and Mrs. Caroline Fitzpatrick, said the new group was formed on the back of the number of planning applications for new homes in the King Street and harbour area in the town.Mr. Davey said people loved both areas for their history and charm, but feared they were ripe to be picked off by developers.He said the delegation had asked to address the council in a bid to help local residents achieve their goals of curtailing the developmentCLOUGH ndash A Loyalist hit list containing the names of target nationalists in the area was uncovered during the search of a farm near Clough last week.Police visited a number of people in the South Down area over the weekend to warn them that their details have fallen into the hands of loyalists paramilitaries.The batch of military intelligence documents were found during a joint police and army raid of the local premises last Monday.A leading loyalist from the area was arrested during the incident but released without charged the following day.At least one Sinn Fein councillor is included on the list, as well as a number of other party members.Some of the documents are  years old, while others contain information from  army files with details of nationalists living in Newcastle, Castlewellan and Newry.KILLYLEAGH ndash Work on Killyleaghrsquos major new waterfront development is currently underway.Contractors moved on site recently to carry our preparatory work to pave the way for the construction of  town houses and  apartments which will look out over Strangford Lough.Over the coming months, the harbour area will be transformed as one of the first major new housing developments planned for the town moves towards completion.The ambitious waterfront proposals have been drawn up by the townrsquos Development Association with the main construction work being caring out by McLaughlin and Harvey.Down Council is also backing the scheme to help regenerate the harbour area and is to provide pound, in funding over the next three years.Meanwhile, the Killyleagh Development Association is currently seeking tenders to construct the planned walkway which is a key feature of the planned new development.It is seeking expressions of interest from piling contractors, earthwork specialists and contractors with experience in concrete, reinforcement and shuttering.MOURNES mdash An accident in the Mournes resulted in a Monaghan woman being flown to the Downe Hospital with a fractured ankle on Monday evening.The  year-old had travelled to the area with friends that morning and was making a descent in an area known as the Happy Valley, near Meelmore and Meelbeg Mountains, which are close to Fofanny Dam, when the accident happened.Members of the Mourne Mountain Rescue Team were called at around pm and after treating the woman at the scene requested a helicopter be flown in to transport her to hospital.Speaking a short time after the incident, Mr Neil Powell, one of the co-ordinators of the local rescue team, explained that one of the womanrsquos friends had immobilised her injured leg with a walking stick and bandages before nine members of the team reached the scene shortly after pm.DOWNPATRICK ndash Planning chiefs have this week pulled the plug on plans by a mobile telephone company to erect a  metre high telecommunications mast near Downpatrick.One  One has been refused permission to erect the mast at Inch Abbey Road, off the main Belfast Road.The move is being hailed as a landmark decision by local councillor Jack McIheron, who believes it is the first time planners have refused to allow a mobile telephone company to erect a telecommunications mast in the district.But while he welcomes the decision, he believes a look at the reasons cited for refusing the application could be applied to literally dozens of sites across the district where planners have already allowed masts to be erected.Mr. McIlheron said the question which has to be addressed is whether there has been a major change in the thinking at the Planning Department, andso, why has it taken so long for it to take on board the concerns of local people and their elected representatives BALLYNAHINCH ndash Local politicians were last night asked to provide a cash boost to help provide new security cameras in Ballynahinch.The request from the townrsquos Regeneration Committee was tabled at a meeting of Down Councilrsquos Cultural and Economic Development Committee.Regeneration officials believe the provision of the so-called spies in the sky can go some way to addressing the vandalism problem which has been dogging the market town over the past few months.The Regeneration Committee is hoping to secure a major slice of a pound.m funding cake which has been made available by the Police Authority to help capture crime on film.ARDGLASS ndash Ardview House in Ardglass will tonight celebrate its th anniversary in style.A festival has been organised to mark the occasion at what is one of the districtrsquos key elderly peoplersquos resource centres.The event will be officially launched by Mrs. Gillian Shaw, the chairman of the Down Lisburn Trust, who will be joined by Down Council chairman Albert Colmer.There will be cake stalls, a tombola, craft stall, aromatherapy demonstration, disco, refreshments, vintage cars and tractors, Irish dancing, line dancing, band and a fortune teller.CASTLEWELLAN ndash Work is to begin shortly in Castlewellan Forest Park on the worldrsquos largest maze.Planning chiefs have this week given the all-clear for , yew trees to be planted on a two-and-a-half acre site inside the forest parkrsquos sprawling grounds.The project will also feature a series of gravel paths, access walkway and a foot-bridge.Officially, known as a Peace Maze, it will be constructed on a hilltop site and is being billed as a further Northern Ireland tourist attraction.The pound, project is being funded by the European Union and people behind the ambitious plan are hoping young people and community groups will help plant what could be one of the provincersquos lar gest ever peace projects.CROSSGAR ndash A new after schools club for all primary school children in the Crossgar area is to be set up next month.From September, Crossgar Community Centre, in conduction with some of the local primary schools, will launch the new club in the villagersquos community centre.The club, which is to have its own management structure comprising representatives and parents from all the participating primary schools, will run during term time..prettyPhoto

title: Hats off to knitting grandmother
story: DEDICATED knitter Anne Degan has a special gt for children starting primary school in Crossgar.The  year-old has knitted more than  bobble hats in school colours and is giving them to every P pupil in St Josephrsquos Primary School and Glasswater Primary School.The local woman is also offering her hats to Cedar Integrated Primary School and a local playgroup.She told the Recorder the free hats are a result of her love of knitting.ldquoI just love knitting and I canrsquot stop it, said the grandmother. ldquoI knit all the time and love to do bobble hats. I have so many of them so I thought there must be a way of doing something practical and passing them on to families and children who might appreciate them.Mrs Degan has been knitting for a letime and gets her wool either online or from The Wool Den in Ballynahinch.She is happy to pay for the wool as the hats are used.ldquoI could not put a figure on what I spend on wool but thatrsquos not the point of it, said Mrs Degan, who also knits bonnets for babies.ldquoI just enjoy knitting and itrsquos lovely to see what I make being put to good use. It would be lovely to see one of the children out in one of my hats this winter.She added: ldquoMy daughter also gives my hats to families through her work so itrsquos just a way to help out..prettyPhoto

title: Lauren goes to Forfar
story: BALLYNAHINCHrsquoS Northerrn Ireland senior international goalkeeper Lauren Perry has completed a move to Scottish club Forfar Farmington ahead of the new season.Nineteen year-old Perry moves to the Scottish WPL  club from Blackburn Rovers after a year at the Ewood Park outfit.Farmington are managed by former Linfield Ladies boss Ryan McConville and Perry will be linking up with fellow Northern Ireland team-mates Billie Simpson, Jade Lindsay and Lauren Brennan at Station Park.Perry could be set to make her competitive debut on the opening day of the season as McConvillersquos troops welcome Motherwell to on October .She boasts five senior caps for the Northern Ireland national team after a player of the match display on her debut against Norway as a -year old.The young shot-stopper has also played Champions League football, making her European bow in - against PK- Vantaa.She has won the Ulster Womenrsquos Player of the Year, NIFWA Womenrsquos Football Personality of the Year, and NIFL Player of the Year awards during her time at Danske Womenrsquos Premiership side Linfield Ladies, where her father, Alan, is assistant manager.At Linfield, Perry picked up three league titles and a League Cup medal before making her move to the FA Womenrsquos Championship to coincide with her university studies.Perry said:Irsquom really excited about the move,ldquoItrsquos a new environment, and I canrsquot wait to get back to playing football.ldquoI expect to come up against tough opposition, but I canrsquot wait to take on the new challenge.New manager McConville said: ldquoI am delighted to finish off our recruitment drive with such a talented signing. Lauren is a goalkeeper with so much talent and experience for such a young player. ldquoldquoShe is a fantastic shot-stopper and is a real modern day goalkeeper, being good with her feet. ldquoldquoWe already have one of the best goalkeeperrsquos in the country in Fiona McNicoll and a great up and coming keeper in Beth Mowatt.ldquoLauren adds to the quality in this department and now our squad has strength and depth all over the park. I canrsquot wait to welcome her to Station Park..prettyPhoto

title: Lighthouse campaign calls for end to change
story: ARCHITECTS of planned changes at the historic St Johnrsquos Point lighthouse have been asked to abort their controversial plan.The Commissioner of Irish Lightsis planning to replace both the current rotating mechanism at the lighthouse and the existing light with a modern, low-powered LED alternative, while retaining the existing Fresnel lens.A campaign group mdash the Lecale Lightkeepers mdashand several local politicians want the controversial proposal scrapped.They have voiced concern that CIL is seeking tenders from specialist companies to remove liquid mercury from St Johnrsquos Point and six other lighthouses across Ireland over the next six years, beginning with two on Rathlin Island.Campaigners and politicians are calling for the proposal to be scrapped and are concerned that tender documents have been issued, despite major opposition to any changes at St Johnrsquos Point.CIL insists it is planning minimal changes and aims to remove mercury from the lighthousersquos current rotating lens mechanism and replace it with a German-made alternative.In addition, the organisation insists that the engineering works planned for the Killough lighthouse will deliver a ldquobetter quality, environmentally superior solution which meets modern health and safety requirements.CIL argues that it is simply removing mercury out of the rotating lens system and putting in an innovative mechanical bearing solution at the lighthouse.However, the claims have been firmly rejected by local people keen to see the controversial plan aborted.According to the tender documents, CIL wants to replace the existing beam with a more environmentally friendly LED light, maintaining that it can do this while retaining the traditional lens.In addition, the organisation says that while mercury has been used to rotate large revolving Fresnel lenses since the s, with the system providing a near frictionless environments, mercury is a ldquotoxic substance.CIL maintains while it has no immediate statutory requirement to remove mercury from lighthouses, it has been its policy that where re-engineering capital projects are being carried out at lighthouses, ldquothe opportunity is taken to remove mercury.The organisation has confirmed that as part of the engineering upgrade works, the mercury will be removed from existing optic installations and replaced by a mechanical bearing to provide an alternative rotation mechanism.CIL maintains that only the liquid mercury will be removed and the remaining apparatus will be retained unchanged.South Down MLA Emma Rogan is one of a number of politicians who wants the sweeping beam retained at the Killough lighthouse and not replaced with an LED alternative.She argues that replacing the existing beam would be ldquodetrimental to the heritage of St Johnrsquos Point lighthouse which has acted as a beacon for ships since .Ms Rogan continued: ldquo The lsquoloom of the lightrsquo which illuminates the Co Down sky is part of the very DNA of Killough and Co Down.ldquoAs well as the vast majority of local residents who are in favour of retaining the light, Newry, Mourne and Down Council has also passed a motion to retain the existing light.Ms Rogan called on CIL to cease acting contrary to the wishes of the community and take on board their view by withdrawing this tender immediately.She added: ldquoI want to commend those involved in campaigning to retain the light as it exists..prettyPhoto

title: Loughinisland go marching on in Senior Championship
story: LOUGHINISLANDrsquoS top flight experience was too much for Darragh Cross in this Senior Football Championship tie at Downpatrick on Saturday.In a game played in slippery conditions due to the incessant rain, the Blues led from the start and never relinquished the lead throughout the match.Darragh Cross deserve much credit for their battling display throughout but Loughinislandrsquos domination the final quarter where scored three unanswered points helped them secure passage through to the next round.Loughinisland manager Jody Gormley was delighted to get his side through to the next round against tough opponents.He said: ldquoA local derby, we thought it was going to be tight given the way that Darragh Cross set up so defensively. They were very effective and very dficult to break down, but I think we showed a lot of patience, kept the ball quite well and got the result mdash thatrsquos what itrsquos all about.ldquoWe were patient when we had the ball, pressed their kick-out well and put them under pressure. We took the chances when they presented themselves and wersquore just happy to be in the hat again.The Blues dominated their first ten minutes but hit four wides and had nothing to show for their hard work. Aaron McClements put their first point on the scoreboard with a free from  metres in the th minute before Darraghrsquos Oisin McConvey was shown the black card by the referee.Ben OrsquoReilly caught a great ball, passed it to McClements who doubled Loughinislandrsquos lead a minute later.Darragh were slowly working their way into the game with Matthew Hardy and Joe McKinney combining well in the middle of the park. A three man move including Mark McMahon, Michael Monan and James Murray saw Monan put the first point on the board for Darragh on the th minute just before the first water break.McKinney then charged through the middle and was fouled before Marcus Miskelly levelled the scores in the st minute.McClements was fouled on his way through the Darragh defence and put the resultant free over the bar to restore his sidersquos lead in the rd minute as Eamonn Sweeney was replaced by Eoin Mageean for Darragh Cross.OrsquoReillyrsquos high ball from distance was spilled by lsquokeeper Rory Miskelly for a  and McClements put the ball over the black spot to put the scores - to - in the th minute. Downrsquos Jonny Flynn then gained possession, passed to Dean McLaughlin, who fed Paddy McKenny to put three between the sides just seconds later.Darragh defender Michael Boyle was then shown a yellow card for a foul on Conor Megoran as Marcus Miskelly scored his second point of the of the match to leave his side two points behind at the halfway mark.Whatever Paul Murphy and Desi McNeill said to their players helped Darragh claw back the deficit within four minutes of the restart.Loughinislandrsquos John McCarthy received a yellow card for a rough tackle on Conleth Sweeney and he pointed from the free in the st minute.Darraghrsquos James Murray then gained possession. He found Joe McKenny coming through from midfield and passed to full forward Shea Boyle, who was subsequently fouled and put the ball over the bar to level the match.It was that man Aaron McClements again who scored five of his sidersquos six points by the th minute to put Loughinisland one in front. Eoin Mageean showed guile, skill and composure with a mazy run from wide on the right to the centre and put the ball over from  metres to level things again in the th minute.Ben OrsquoReilly was getting his fare share of possession and fed Conor Megoran to put Loughinisland - to - at the second water break.It appeared the game could swing any way at this stage and Darragh Cross equalised again after Marcus Miskelly scored a magnicent point off the upright from  metres. However, that was as good as it got as Loughinisland dominated the final quarter to secure the win.In a free-flowing move McClements found Ben OrsquoReilly, who scored a delightful point in the th minute. Aiden Nixon came on to replace Rory Deegan for Loughinisland but suffered a reoccurrence of an ankle injury and was replaced by Eddie Nixon just seconds after coming on.Rory Mason scored a great point from  metres with his left foot in the th minute just before Mark McMahon received a yellow card for the Darragh Cross.With victory in sight, Conor Megoran passed to substitute Eddie Nixon and he fisted the ball over the bar for Loughinisland to send his team safely through to the next round of the championship.Darragh Cross: R Miskelly P Branny, M Monan , E Sweeney M Boyle, O McConvey, C Murray M Hardy, J McKinney M McMahon, M Miskelly , J Murray, S Dineen, S Boyle , C Sweeney . Subs: E Mageeanfor E Sweeney, E Sweeney for Boyle, J Flynn for C Sweeney.Loughinisland: C Turley C OrsquoToole, P Megoran, S Cochrane R Mason , D Gordon, D McLoughlin, J Flynn, D OrsquoToole B OrsquoReilly , D McClements , J McCarthy R Deegan, P McKenny , C Megoran . Subs: A Nixon for R Deegan, E Nixonfor A Nixon, T McDonald for C Megoran.Referee: C Gribben..prettyPhoto

title: Matthew ready for film festival
story: A FILM written and directed by a Downpatrick man has secured a place at next monthrsquos th International Underground Cinema Film Festival in Dublin.Matthew Killen is the creative force behind Beach Baby which was filmed in Downpatrick and Newcastle.The  year-old Matthew originated the concept for Beach Baby whilst studying on the HND Creative Media Production at the South Eastern Regional Collegersquos Bangor Campus.He later developed theand secured funding to remake the film and better realise his vision after he graduated from the collegersquos Northern Ireland Film and Television School.He said: ldquoWe are thrilled that Beach Baby has been selected for the th International Underground Cinema Film Festival.ldquoIt will be one of a hundred films selected for screen over the three days of the festival. You never know who will be watching your film or what connections might be made on the back of a screening.He said that Beach Baby had been entered into  festivals from Dublin, London, Toronto and Vancouver.ldquoIt will hopefully have a good run at festivals before we pitch it to cinemas or a social site where everyone will have the chance to see it, said Matthew, adding: ldquoI am very proud of the work and everyone who contributed to getting it over the line mdash just before we went into lockdown.Matthew explained more about his film: ldquoBeach Baby is a modern-day drama that follows Ethan and Chloe, a young couple whose relationship is tested when they find out that Ethan has lung cancer and Chloe is pregnant. We follow their journey together as we see them trying to deal with this sudden change in both their lives.The film, set in Belfast, was also shot on location in Bangor. It stars Dublin actors Marie Devine and Shane Brohan with Shannen Lofthouse and Jake Douglas from Northern Ireland. The film score was composed by Stephen Kavanagh, also from Dublin.Matthew said that while it took a week to shoot, this was followed by a year-long editing process. ldquoI called in favours, left, right and centre and ran a fundraising campaign through Indiegogo which raised over pound, the majority of which was used to pay the composer for the score with the actors, all of whom I know, donating their amazing talents and skills, said Matthew.ldquoItrsquos fantastic to know that they had as much conviction and belief in the script as myself. I am overwhelmed with their generosity and investment of talent in making Beach Baby a reality and exactly how I wanted it to be completed.Asmaking your own film is not proof enough of Matthewrsquos talent, he is also a musician, playing drummer with local band Wynona Bleach. The band are getting ready for the release of their debut album Moonsoake in October.Recorded in rural Portugal, the band received funding from Help Musicians NI and the Arts Council NI to make the album.Matthew said, ldquoI originally studied music production many years ago at SERCrsquos Downpatrick campus and progressed to the HND in Music Production at the Bangor Campus.ldquoAs well as being a musician, I ended up creating all the music videos and documentaries for Wynona Bleach.ldquoThis spurred me toto SERC to further improve my knowledge in film production where I did a part-time HNC Creative Media at the Ballynahinch Campus in  and then went on to do my HND Creative Media Production at the Bangor Campus in . I was also back at the college in , lecturing Single Camera Techniques for TV part-time for the same course.SERC media lecturer Alison Thompson spoke highly of her former studentrsquos achievements.ldquoMatty was a distinction student at SERC. she added. ldquoHe is an incredibly talented guy and very driven to succeed in the industry. He had the vision to develop Beach Baby and we are delighted that his determination got it over the line.ldquoIt is unfortunate that the premiere, planned for the annual NIFTS Showcase at the Strand Cinema, Belfast in June had to be cancelled due to Covid-.ldquoWe are incredibly proud of his success and are looking forward to following Beach Babyrsquos festival run mdash and hopefully picking up a few accolades along the way.Follow BeachBabyFilm on Facebook to keep up to date as to where and when you can watch the film..prettyPhoto

title: New housing scheme planned for Crossgar
story: CROSSGAR could be in line for a major new housing scheme,ambitious development proposals are given the green light.Planning permission is being sought to bulldoze the former Villager restaurant and bar, with the car park at the rear also included in the development plan for  new apartments.Sixteen of the proposed apartments will be two-bed properties with the remaining four featuring just one bed.The site borders Downpatrick Street and Kilmore Street and papers lodged with local planners confirm that the two-storey former bar and restaurant ceased trading five years ago.There are three elements to the Crossgar proposal which include the demolition of the existing pub and restaurant, the construction of new residential apartments and the creation of new amenity space, landscaping, clothes drying and bin storage facilities.The company behind the proposal is confident that it can make a positive contribution to Crossgarrsquos streetscape.Seventeen car parking spaces will be provided in a courtyard at the rear, with four of these overhung by first and second floor apartments.Developers argue that the shortfall of spaces can be accommodated at nearby off-street parking in Downpatrick Street.The development proposal also includes planting a number of trees along Kilmore Street with developers confident that the planned investment represents a ldquohigh quality scheme that will represent a quality, residential environment appropriate to its prominent location..prettyPhoto

title: Our message is all about staying at home%2C supporting local
story: NORTHERN Irelandrsquos top tourism chief was on some very familiar ground when he paid a recent visit to the district.Tourism NI chief executive John McGrillen visited a number of businesses including Castlewellanrsquos Le Adventure Centre, Downpatrickrsquos Denvirrsquos Coaching Inn and Ballynahinchrsquos Montalto estate.In addition to meeting with local tourism industry representatives, he also met up with Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairwoman Laura Devlin.Mr McGrillen, who was a former chief executive of the old Down Council, spoke with owners and staff across a number of businesses in the tourism and hospitality sector in the area to learn about the measures they have put in place to ensure the safety of visitors and staff.During his visit, he heard about their respective concerns as they try to navigate through very challenging times as a result of Covid-.ldquoOur message in Northern Ireland is about staying at home, supporting local and focusing on the fact that we have a tremendous tourism product right on our doorstep, said Mr McGrillen.ldquoTo promote this locally and to our visitors coming across the border, we launched our marketing campaign at the end of June featuring our new brand, Northern Ireland Embrace a Giant Spirit.The tourism chief revealed that in a typical year, % of overnight tourism spend is domestic, explaining that as less people travel abroad for their holidays, it is a great opportunity for the domestic market to explore all that is wonderful about Northern Ireland.Mr McGrillen continued: ldquoThis year we can stay local while still getting away from it all and in doing so you will be supporting an industry that is so important to our economy.The tourism official thanked the local council and representatives from the ldquofantastic local businesses he had an opportunity to meet with during his recent visit.He added: ldquoIt was great seeing so many people, locally and from the Republic of Ireland, enjoy all the brilliant hoteliers, tour guides, restauranteurs and visitor attractions in the area.ldquoOur tourism industry has seriously suffered from the effects of the lockdown. As we move through a period of recovery, we are sending a very clear message that your favourite places, as well as those yet to be discovered, are working very hard to give visitors a warm and safe welcome back.Cllr Devlin said it was ldquogreat to welcome Mr McGrillen back to the district to visit.ldquoJohn visited some of the businesses offering experiences, accommodation and outdoor activities which are critical to economic recovery as we encourage people to enjoy a staycation in , she said.ldquoNewry, Mourne and Down Council is working in partnership with Tourism NI and our local businesses to rebuild the value of tourism in the district..prettyPhoto

title: Popular minister bids farewell
story: PARISHIONERS from Down and Hollymount Churches said farewell to their departing minister during a special service last Sunday morning.The Rev Captain Scott McDonald is leaving Downpatrick to take up a new post in Newry, four years after he was appointed to look after the local Church of Ireland congregations.Social distancing measures were in place for the weekend service which was also streamed live via Facebook to provide people at home with an opportunity to watch it.The departing minister was joined by his we Pauline and daughter Kerry, with other clergy who took part in the service including the Dean of Down, the Very Rev Henry Hull, the Rev Adrian Dorrian and the Rev Julie Bell.Presentations were made to Mr McDonald and his we by David Telford from Down Parish Church and Maureen Blair from Hollymount Church.During his address, Mr McDonald said that he and his we had been ldquooverwhelmed by the messages of goodwill and the many gts that they had received.He said that while ldquoclergy come and go, God remains faithful and will continue to be with both congregations, recalling how met with the Dean in  ahead of his subsequent appointment to minister locally.ldquoIt has truly been a joy and privilege to be with you and to walk with you for the past four years, through the ups and downs of family le. There have been sad times but there has also been as joyful times, said Mr McDonald.ldquoWe want to say thank you for your welcome for us as a family. You have been generous and been there for us when you have been needed. I want you to understand that you are Godrsquos church and that under the leadership of Dean Henry, Adrian, Julie and others, Godrsquos work here will go from strength to strength and I really believe that.Recalling some of the initiatives he introduced including the menrsquos breakfasts and Carols by the Lake at Ballydugan, he said a number of other events were planned for the summer but unfortunately did not take place due to Covid-.The departing minister said that one of the joys of ministering in Downpatrick was seeing the opening of the Pepper Johns Community Centre adjacent to the Parochial Hall in Church Avenue. He said while it was going from strength to strength, Covid did have an impact, but he was confident there was a bright future ahead for the building and the services that it will deliver.Mr McDonald said he trusted that when the pandemic ends, the congregations will get behind Alison Carson who runs the community facility which exists to meet the needs of people. He said the impact of the small building mdash redeveloped by the Parish Church mdash was expanding all the time.He added: ldquoI know that you will protect and encourage all that happens from there.Dean Hull paid tribute to Mr McDonaldrsquos contribution to not only Down and Hollymount churches but all those within the Lecale Area Mission Partnershipgroup.ldquoScott made a signicant contribution to LAMP and he and his family have been very much part of le here in Down and in Hollymount, also touching on the other churches within the group as well.ldquoScottrsquos ministry very much focused on Down Parish and Hollymount but he has influenced people in churches where and there are those who are sad that they cannot be with us this morning, the Dean continued.Praising Mr McDonald for launching Carols by the Lake and Blue Christmas initiatives, Dean Hull said the latter really touched those dealing with bereavement and loss and hopes that bothcontinue to feature on the church calendar.Mr Dorrian highlighted the key role played by Scott in forging relationships, referencing his work with the Pepper Johns Community Centre and establishing a link betweenHollymount Church and Hollymount Pipe Band. One of the bandrsquos members, Sam Gill, played at the end of Sundayrsquos service.Mr Telford described Sundayrsquos service as a ldquosad occasion as the congregation in Down Parish said goodbye to their minister who had touched all their lives.He said Mr McDonaldrsquos arrival in  ldquosparked renewed optimism within the church with the new man quickly making his mark, especially in relation to the Pepper Johns Community Centre which he helped deliver along with the board of trustees.He added: ldquoPerhaps the best tribute that can be paid to Scott is that he very soon became one of us and, deep down, I think he knows that he always will be. It was a hard decision for Scott and his family to make the move to Newry and it is important that while we are disappointed aboutthis, we support them and continue to do so.On behalf of Hollymount Church, Ms Blair said that Mr McDonald will be very much missed, praising him for his leadership and the ious initiatives that he spearheaded over the past four years.ldquoWe are all fond of Scott who was with us through thick and thin and ups and downs. No matter what, Scott was there, she said.Ms Blair added: ldquoWhile we are sorry to see him go, we wish Scott and his family all the best in Newry..prettyPhoto

title: Students celebrate GCSE results after ‘challenging year’
story: IT was a dferent GCSE results day this year for local schools and students as the need to maintain social distancing measures was a key concern.As with the recent A-Level results, grades this year were predicted by teachers as examinations could not be held due to schools closure over the Covid- lockdown.Down High Schoolrsquos principal, Mrs Maud Perry, reported that  students collected their results from two designated venues in Downpatrick at dferent times with social distancing measures in place.Nearly % of all students achieved at least seven A* A grades while six pupils mdash Katie Dickson, Ellen Johnston, Cameron McCaughey, Lauren McCormick, Rosa Morgan-Young and Anna Torrens mdash all received ten A* grades while Lucy Healy and Tori Marks secured nine A* grades each.Mrs Perry paid tribute to the hard work of her pupils during such challenging times.ldquoThis was a lovely year group and we congratulate them on these outcomes, which provide a firm foundation for the next stage of their education. Our pupils are academically able, but only when this is combined with consistent hard work and effort can excellence be reached, she said.ldquoWe relish the prospect of working with these outstanding young people as they embark upon their A-Level studies.Mr Joe McCann, principal of St Patrickrsquos Grammar School, welcomed the decision by examining bodies which upheld the GCSE grades calculated by the teachers.Describing the decision as providing a ldquopositive conclusion for the schoolrsquos Year  students, he said: ldquoThankfully our Year  students did not have to suffer the same anxiety and stress as the Year  students had to last week.ldquoThis meant that there were no shocks or disappointments on GCSE results day with students receiving the grades they had been working hard to achieve. This has ensured a positive conclusion for our outgoing Year  students at the end of a dficult and challenging year.Year  students at St Maryrsquos High School continued the schoolrsquos upward trajectory in performance with % achieving five or more GCSE passes at A*-C with % of these also achieving passes at A*-C in English and Mathematics.Miss Rosemary McLaughlin, principal, said: ldquoThis yearrsquos results follow the amazing results the school achieved in  when St Maryrsquos was ranked fourth place in Northern Ireland in the league tables for non-selective schools.ldquoWe would like to thank our staff for their dedication to the students and for ensuring that lsquoEvery Child Mattersrsquo.Mr Ciaran Maguire, principal of De La Salle High School in Downpatrick, congratulated his students on their achievements.He also welcomed the change in the Minister of Educationrsquos policy towards GCSErsquos grades and the use of CentreAssessment Grade as opposed to the algorithm, previously applied to AS and A-Level results.ldquoSeeing so many smiles and relief across our students faces was very welcoming, he added.ldquoThe stress and pressure all young people have been under since the lockdown cannot be taken lightly or even ignored just because of percentages. Every young man that came through our doors this morning has a Covid story and they are still living in it.The principal of The High School, Ballynahinch, Mr Paul Marks, said that while staff and students were pleased with ldquoexcellent GCSE results, they wished it had been under better circumstances.He remarked: ldquoWe missed saying goodbye properly to our Year  pupils, but we are glad that all of our pupils received the grades they worked so hard for.ldquoAs a school we do not measure ourselves just against results alone. What is also very important to us is that we have happy children.St Colmcillersquos High School in Crossgar reported that % of its students received five or more GCSEs grades A* to C.Mr Seamus Hanna called his Year  students ldquoamazing and talked of a bright future for the school with an increase in new Year  students.He said: ldquoWe are delighted that the genuine efforts of all our pupils and their parents and carers have been recognised and these results will empower our pupils to make positive le choices for their futures.Mr Mark Morgan, principal of St Colmanrsquos High and Sixth Form College in Ballynahinch, said that his studentsrsquo results were in keeping with the schoolrsquos normal trends.ldquoOur results were very encouraging mdash % of students received at least five A* to C grades % of students received at least seven A* to C grades and % of students received at least five A* to C grades including English and Mathematics, he said.ldquoThese fabulous results are testament to the hard work and dedication of our pupils, staff and parents and all should be commended for their effort and achievement.The principal of St Malachyrsquos High School in Castlewellan described this yearrsquos results as ldquooutstanding with % of students achieving A*-C grades in five or more subjects.Mrs Orla McNeill said that the schoolrsquos previous high standards gained in previous years had been exceeded with many students securing several A* and A grades in a wide range of subjects.ldquoOur young people have been put through a lot over the last few months and it was only fitting that they received the results that they worked hard for and that their teachers, who know them best, predicted, she said.Mrs OrsquoNeill praised the students, teachers and parents, adding: ldquoThese wonderful results are very well deserved, reflecting everyonersquos hard work and commitment not only after five years in St Malachyrsquos but also bearing in mind the excellent foundations laid in our ldquofeeder primary schools.Mr Kevin Lambe, principal of Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle, said: ldquoThe GCSE results have been a triumph in so many ways. Our students have fulfilled their potential, from those with straight As and A*s and throughout the range and combinations of grades.ldquoRecord numbers of students will progress to A level and others are heading off to apprenticeships and further education courses to follow their chosen career. This has been such a challenging year, and students and staff are delighted that, with safety precautions all in place, we will be able to move ahead on a sound foundation of outstanding achievement.Blackwater Integrated College in Downpatrick described its results as ldquoexcellent.The principal, Mr Stephen Taylor, said it was a year to congratulate every student for what they attained in such ldquounusual and often challenging circumstances.He noted that the schoolrsquos outgoing head boy, Conor Phillips, and head girl, Holly Ritchie, both achieved A*-C in at least seven subjects, along with Aliesha Brown, who passed all of her subjects with A* and B grades.He said: ldquoThe fact that students have built upon the excellent results achieved in  and surpassed those highlights the hard work that was put in by every student. Over % of our students achieved five or more A*-C grades at GCSE which is an outstanding achievement..prettyPhoto

title: Successful end to speech and drama sessions
story: A LOCAL speech and drama group has brought its summer sessions to a close.Dorans Academy of Speech and Drama, is situated on the Ardilea Road, outside Clough.Itrsquos one-to-one and bubble classes provided fantastic fun and the children progressed quickly in the focused sessions.All classes continued seamlessly through the lockdown period, via Zoom, which enabled the children to continue progressing and developing.While the children looked forward to the weekly online release from isolation, it was not the same as being in the same room and the summer one-to-ones and bubble classes saw the enthusiasm clearly oozing.ldquoIt has been fantastic to work with the children in my private studio again safely, with so much space, said Michelle Dorans.ldquoThey were so enthusiastic and delighted to be in studio for the first time since lockdown.Michelle says she canrsquot wait to get the groups back in September, albeit with reduced class sizes to mitigate risk during these uncertain times.ldquoChildhood is such a crucial time of le, building skills that see us through our entire journey wherever it may take us, she said.ldquoIt is vital to keep balance and encourage children into activities while ensuring to mitigate the risks the current climate sees us in. Keeping a healthy balance as always for mind and body is important.Michelle says she is looking forward to the future and seeing how children can develop their talents.ldquoAll children, from three year-olds to teenagers, will be warmly welcomed, she remarked.ldquoI am so passionate about speech and drama and all that it entails, building children up, providing a  to perform and merge, as well as to harness and develop the skills and talents from all areas of their le.Classes at Dorans Academy of Speech and Drama resume next month. For further information contact  , or michelledorans@hotmail..prettyPhoto

title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair

Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. title: mlas hike salaries their staff taking them above some doctors pay
story: Is there a case for the Union  Yes – and it’s stronger than everActor Jimmy Nesbitt reveals howthe recent loss of his father brought home trauma for families as ‘International Day of the Disappeared’ was heldNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsPoliticsMLAs hike salaries for their staff, taking them above some doctors’ payJust two months after MLAs controversially voted toreverse a key reform made in the wake of the expenses scandal and ed to themselves the power to set their own expenses, they have hiked the pay of their staff.By Sam McBrideFriday, th August , : pm""MLAs’ staff – some of whom are family members – can now earn up to £, a yearThe scale of the increase is such that the best paid workers in MLAs’ constituency offices – many of whom are family members of the MLA or party colleagues – will see the upper limit of their pay soar by % to £,.That will take their pay higher than that of some registrar doctors working in hospitals whose pay scale begins at £, a year and involves years of study, both in university and in the hospital, to get to that point where they are caring for acutely ill patients.Yesterday Alan McQuillan, the former PSNI deputy chief constable who was one of the independent  members who for most of the last decade set MLAs’ pay and expenses independently, questioned why staff in an MLA’s office taking phone calls, writing lettersand similar jobs – and perhaps with no qualications – would be paid more than a doctor. " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...Mr McQuillian told Talkback that it was an “amazing” pay hike and he could find no reference to any comparable pay deal anywhere in the public sector in Northern Ireland.The change to the rules by MLAs will also mean an increase in expenses they can claim for their offices, mobile phones and multiple other areas of expenditure – which could total about £ million a year.People Before Profit MLA Gerry Carroll said the decision was “absolutely wrong” and “is exactly this kind of ‘gravy train’ politics that has left many thousands of people disillusioned with Stormont”.TUV leader Jim Allister said that MLAs setting their own allowances “lacks the independent rigour the public rightly expects”.But independent MLA Jim Wells argued that the move merely put staff on to the same footing as civil servants who work in the Assembly.The Assembly told the News Letter that MLAs had examined other public sector roles – but not included the private sector, as Mr McQuillan’s  had done – when deciding to set the new staff salaries and the changes would “bring MLA staff into broad alignment with them”.Edwina Hegarty, a specialistinfectious diseases and microbiology registrar working in the NHS in Northern Ireland, told the News Letter that she was not knowledgeable about what MLAs’ staff do and so“what they’re worth is not for me to say”.However, she said that there was about seven years of work and vast expense involved before a doctor gets to be a registrar and that the nature of the job is that sometimes doctors will stay in work three hours after their finish time to care for a sick patient.Read More Read MoreMLAs vote to set their own expenses again – despite warning of potential for abuse________A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website.
